source:
ABSTRACT.BACKGROUND:
Metabolic syndrome is a cluster of common cardiovascular risk factors that includes hypertension and insulin resistance. Hypertension and diabetes mellitus are frequent comorbidities and, like metabolic syndrome, increase the risk of cardiovascular events. Telmisartan, an antihypertensive agent with evidence of partial peroxisome proliferator-activated receptor activity-gamma (PPARγ) activity, may improve insulin sensitivity and lipid profile in patients with metabolic syndrome.

ABSTRACT.METHODS:
In a double-blind, parallel-group, randomized study, patients with World Health Organization criteria for metabolic syndrome received once-daily doses of telmisartan (80 mg, n = 20) or losartan (50 mg, n = 20) for 3 months. At baseline and end of treatment, fasting and postprandial plasma glucose, insulin sensitivity, glycosylated haemoglobin (HBA1c) and 24-hour mean systolic and diastolic blood pressures were determined.

ABSTRACT.RESULTS:
Telmisartan, but not losartan, significantly (p < 0.05) reduced free plasma glucose, free plasma insulin, homeostasis model assessment of insulin resistance and HbAic. Following treatment, plasma glucose and insulin were reduced during the oral glucose tolerance test by telmisartan, but not by losartan. Telmisartan also significantly reduced 24-hour mean systolic blood pressure (p < 0.05) and diastolic blood pressure (p < 0.05) compared with losartan.

ABSTRACT.CONCLUSION:
As well as providing superior 24-hour blood pressure control, telmisartan, unlike losartan, displayed insulin-sensitizing activity, which may be explained by its partial PPARγ activity.
target: Metabolic syndrome is a group of risk factors for heart disease, including high blood pressure and insulin resistance. Losartan, an antihypertensive agent, was compared to telmisartan, which has evidence of partial peroxisome proliferator-activated receptor activity-gamma (PPARγ) activity. The study found that telmisartan, but not losartan, reduced free plasma glucose, free plasma insulin, homeostasis model assessment of insulin resistance and HbA1c. It also reduced 24-hour mean systolic and diastolic blood pressures compared to losartan. These results suggest that telmisartan may be more effective than losartan in treating metabolic syndrome.</s><s>

annotation.final_commands: Please include more information about the study-design.

annotation.pico_pop_rat: The summary does not say that patients with WHO criteria for metabolic syndrome were included in the study. It mentions the Syndrom, but not that the population with this Syndrom was included in this double-blind study.

annotation.pico_inter_rat: The intervention described is Telmisartan and it is accurately described according to the original input.

annotation.pico_comp_rat: The comparator described is Losartan and it is accurately described according to the original input.

annotation.pico_out_rat: The summary meantions free plasma glucose, free plasma insulin, homeostasis model assessment of insulin resistance and HbA1c levels and the blood pressure at different times as outcome correctly.

target:
Metabolic syndrome is a condition that comes with several health issues like high blood pressure and problems in how the body uses sugar. Both the condition and its individual issues can lead to heart disease. There's a medicine named Telmisartan that doctors give people with high blood pressure. People think it could also help with how the body uses sugar and might improve other aspects of metabolic syndrome.

They did a trial where they picked some patients who had metabolic syndrome and divided them into two groups. For three months, one group took Telmisartan every day, while the other group took another drug named Losartan.

By the end of the trial, the group that took Telmisartan showed better results. They had lower sugar levels, the body used sugar more efficiently, and lower hemoglobin A1c, a measure of blood sugar over time. They also had lower blood pressure at all times compared to those who took Losartan. It seems that Telmisartan helped the body use sugar more efficiently partly because it works partially as a PPARγ controller (which is like a switch inside your cells that helps manage sugar and fat). 

In summary, the medicine Telmisartan was better at managing blood pressure and helped improve how the body uses sugar, unlike Losartan. This means it could be useful for people suffering from metabolic syndrome.

annotation.final_commands: Please include the levels of plasma insulin.

annotation.pico_pop_rat: The patients included in this study are correctly mentioned as individuals having metabolic syndrome and that they were divided into two groups for the trial. This suits the original abstract.

annotation.pico_inter_rat: The intervention described is Telmisartan and it is accurately described according to the original input.

annotation.pico_comp_rat: The comparator described is Losartan, this is correct according to the Abstract but the summary does not mention that Losartan is also a medication against high blood pressure and from the same "family" as Telmisartan. It makes it sound like Losartan would just be "any other" drug.

annotation.pico_out_rat: The outcomes mentioned are the level of sugar in the blood, the HbA1c, blood pressure, but it is missing the plasma insulin levels and the homeostasis model assessment of insulin which are named in the Abstract.

annotation.hal_rationale: This information makes somewhat sense but is not totally accurate - neither in describing the Syndrom or the Original text.

target:
This study looked at two medications, telmisartan and losartan, to see which one is better for people with a condition called metabolic syndrome. Metabolic syndrome is when you have a bunch of health problems like high blood pressure and high blood sugar. The study found that telmisartan is better than losartan because it helps lower blood sugar and blood pressure more than losartan does. Telmisartan also helps your body use insulin better, which can help prevent health problems like diabetes.
So, telmisartan is like a superhero for your body! It helps keep your blood sugar and blood pressure under control, and it even has special powers that help your body use insulin better.

annotation.final_commands: Please use more formal language (words like ' superhero' or 'special powers' sound ridiculous). Please explain better what a Metabolic Syndrom is. Please explain what sort of drugs Telmisartan and Losartan are.

annotation.pico_pop_rat: It is mentioned that "people with a condition named Metabolic Syndrom shall benefit from this study but it does not say that the study was made with a group of patients having a metabolic syndrome. Also the metabolic Syndrom itself is explained somewhat vague and inaccurately compared to the information given in the original.

annotation.pico_inter_rat: The intervention mentioned in the summary is Telmisartan, but it is not mentioned that one group of patience with metabolic syndrome was only given this drug and another group Losartan. It is also missing in the summary what type of medication these drugs are ("used to treat patience with too high blood pressure") and neither what characteristics make the difference in between these  two drugs, as explained in the background from the abstract original.

annotation.pico_comp_rat: Just like described in the PICO Interventions Losartan is mentioned in the Summary, yet all further information concerning the medication is missing.

annotation.pico_out_rat: The summary mentions part of the outcome like the blood sugar level and blood pressure, but it does not mention the HbA1c, neither the plasma insulin levels nor the homeostasis model assessment of insulin resistance. It only says in the summary that "the body uses insulin better", but all explanations in what way and by what outcome that is measured by are missing

annotation.results_rat: It does mention that Temisartan helps the patients blood sugar levels and blood pressure, yet it also includes results that are not fully correct, so I would rather chose "for the most part Accurate but also somewhat inaccurate". Also it is inaccurate in the summary that Losartan helps lower blood sugar, only less than Telmisartan.

annotation.con_rationale: The summary makes it sound like Losartan had an effect on the glucose levels and sugar metabolism where the original clearly says that it does not have any effect. The original does say Losartan lowers blood pressure, yet not as significantly  as Temisartan
The summary draws a wrong conclusion and gives a wrong idea of what the criteria for Metabolic Syndrom are.

The summary exaggerates, using informal language, the effects of Telmisartan compared to the results from the original abstract. Temisartan does not keep blood pressure and blood sugar fully "under control" but it has a psoitivly lowering effect on both outcomes. It does not have a special power though - yet it has a positive effect on the homeostasis model assessment of insulin and the free plasma insulin levels.

source:
ABSTRACT.
Thalassemia is the commonest single gene disorder in India. About 10,000 infants with Thalassemia major are born every year. The present study was under taken with a hope to prevail better quality of life to the Thalassemic patients. Pallor being the chief complaint, a randomized controlled trial was undertaken with Dhatri Avaleha as it is specially mentioned for Pandu, Kamala & Haleemaka Roga. Children between age group of 1 to 15 years were randomly divided in two groups: Drug treated group (Group A) and Control group (Group B). Assessment was done on subjective and objective parameters after 30 and 60 days of treatment with follow up of two month. Statistically significant (P<0.01) result was obtained in Blood transfusion interval in group 'A' in comparison to group 'B'. Dhatri Avaleha may have a potential to increase blood transfusion interval and decrease secondary infection and thus it can be used as supportive therapy with modern medical management.
target: Thalassemia is a genetic disorder that is common in India, with around 10,000 infants born with the condition each year. The aim of this study was to improve the quality of life for these patients. Pallor was the main complaint, so a randomized controlled trial was conducted with Dhatri Avaleha, a traditional remedy mentioned for Pandu, Kamala and Haleemaka Roga. Children between the ages of 1 and 15 were randomly divided into two groups: a drug-treated group (Group A) and a control group (Group B). Assessments were done after 30 and 60 days of treatment, with follow-up of two months. The results showed a statistically significant (P<0.01) decrease in the number of blood transfusions in Group A compared to Group B. Dhatri Avaleha may have potential to reduce the number of blood transfusions, decrease the risk of secondary infections, and improve the quality of life for Thalassemic patients.</s><s>

annotation.final_commands: Please explain following terms: Dhatri Avaleha, Pandu, Kamala and Haleemaka Roga - what sort of traditional remedy are these?

annotation.pico_pop_rat: The population of Children between ages 1 and 15 and Thalassemia were mentioned in the summary correctly compared to the information given in the abstract.

annotation.pico_inter_rat: The drug treated group A (as mentioned in the abstrect) is mentioned in the summary correctly.

annotation.pico_comp_rat: The non drug treated group B is mentioned in the summary as a comparator to group A, just like written in the abstract.

annotation.pico_out_rat: The number of blood transfusions and the number of infections are mentioned in the summary as Outcome, just like in the original.

target: This study was done to help improve the lives of patients with Thalassemia, a blood disease that is the most common single gene disorder in India and affects about 10,000 new born babies each year. The main problem for these patients is that they look pale because their blood does not have enough healthy red cells. The researchers did an experiment with two groups of children between ages 1 to 15. One group was given a drug called Dhatri Avaleha, which is known to help with symptoms similar to those caused by Thalassemia. The other group did not receive the drug. After checking these children for 60 days, the scientists found that the children who took the drug needed blood transfusions less often than the others. This suggests that Dhatri Avaleha might be useful to help manage Thalassemia along with other medical treatments.

annotation.final_commands: Please include and explain Pandu, Kamala and Haleemaka Roga. Please include the result that group A had a decrease in secondary infections.

annotation.pico_pop_rat: The Population of children between 1 to 15 and Thalassemia are mentioned in the summary correctly.

annotation.pico_inter_rat: The intervention Group A, that was treated with the drug is mentioned in the summary correctly. It is even well explained in the summary why the drug Dhatri Avaleha was chosen as an Intervention.

annotation.pico_comp_rat: The other Group of children is mentioned correctly, to not have received any drug. Yet it would have been useful to describe the two different groups with A and B just like in the original abstract

annotation.pico_out_rat: The summary identifies the outcome as the number of blood transfusions needed - which is correct, yet it misses to mention the occurance of secondary infections.

The medicine was given to some kids who had Thalassemia, and the results showed that it helped them feel better. The medicine made their blood transfusions more frequent, and they were less likely to get sick. The study showed that the medicine can be used to help people with Thalassemia feel better and live a better life.

annotation.final_commands: Please explain what Dhatri Avaleha is. Please explain which patients in India are affected in India in what way. Please explain what it means that "it made their blood transfusions more frequent". Please explain the set up of the study (mention the population and the two groups).

annotation.pico_pop_rat: It is mentioned that "the drug was given to some kids" yet the exact ages are missing, which are critical cause generally "kids" would be all people ages 1-18 (or 21 - depending on the culture).

annotation.pico_inter_rat: The group of children between 1-15 in group B which are not treated with the drug are not mentioned at all in the summary.

annotation.pico_comp_rat: The comparator from the Abstract (a group of children 1-15 that receive no drugs) is not mentioned at all in the summary.

annotation.pico_out_rat: The summary mentions the comparator: frequency of blood transfusions and likeness to get sick, which are mostly correct, yet it is not further explained (I would find that helpful) and that the "sickness" means secondary infections is not mentioned.

annotation.results_rat: The summary says correctly that the study showa that the bloodtransfusions are more frequent and that the treated children are less likely to get sick - yet the conclusion that the medicine would def help people with Thalassemia feel better and live a better live is Inaccurate from my point of understanding. The abstract  came to the more humble conclusion that the medicine can be used to support therapy with modern medical management - where the summary makes it sound like this drug is all that patience would need.

annotation.hal_rationale: It sounds like an exaggeration to me to conclude that the treated kids "live a better life" just by taking the drug.

source:
ABSTRACT.BACKGROUND:
Nasal insufflation of CO2 has been shown to exert antinociceptive respectively antihyperalgesic effects in animal pain models using topical capsaicin with activation of TRPV1-receptor positive nociceptive neurons. Clinical benefit from CO2 inhalation in patients with craniofacial pain caused by a putative activation of TRPV1 receptor positive trigeminal neurons has also been reported. These effects are probably mediated via an activation of TRPV1 receptor - positive neurons in the nasal mucosa with subsequent central inhibitory effects (such as conditioned pain modulation). In this study, we aimed to examine the effects of intranasal CO2 on a human model of craniofacial pain elicited by nasal application of capsaicin.

ABSTRACT.METHODS:
In a first experiment, 48 healthy volunteers without previous craniofacial pain received intranasal capsaicin to provoke trigeminal pain elicited by activation of TRVP1 positive nociceptive neurons. Then, CO2 or air was insufflated alternatingly into the nasal cavity at a flow rate of 1 l/min for 60 sec each. In the subsequent experiment, all participants were randomized into 2 groups of 24 each and received either continuous nasal insufflation of CO2 or placebo for 18:40 min after nociceptive stimulation with intranasal capsaicin. In both experiments, pain was rated on a numerical rating scale every 60 sec.

ABSTRACT.RESULTS:
Contrary to previous animal studies, the effects of CO2 on experimental trigeminal pain were only marginal. In the first experiment, CO2 reduced pain ratings only minimally by 5.3% compared to air if given alternatingly with significant results for the main factor GROUP (F1,47 = 4.438; p = 0.041) and the interaction term TIME*GROUP (F2.6,121.2 = 3.3; p = 0.029) in the repeated-measures ANOVA. However, these effects were abrogated after continuous insufflation of CO2 or placebo with no significant changes for the main factors or the interaction term.

ABSTRACT.CONCLUSIONS:
Although mild modulatory effects of low-flow intranasal CO2 could be seen in this human model of TRPV-1 mediated activation of nociceptive trigeminal neurons, utility is limited as observed changes in pain ratings are clinically non-significant.
target: In this study, we examined the effects of intranasal carbon dioxide (CO2) on a human model of craniofacial pain caused by activation of TRPV1-positive nociceptive neurons. We found that CO2 had mild modulatory effects on pain ratings in this model, with these effects being seen only in the first experiment, in which CO2 was given alternatingly with air. However, these effects were abrogated after continuous insufflation of CO2 or placebo, with no significant changes for the main factors or the interaction term. Therefore, the utility of intranasal CO2 in this model is limited, as the observed changes in pain ratings are clinically non-significant.</s><s>

annotation.final_commands: Please give more information about the used methods and background of the study. Please explain what "TRPV1-positive nociceptive neurons" are with simple terms.

annotation.pico_pop_rat: Not enough information about the population as described in the abstract are given in the summary. It only names "humans" what seems too vague to me, as it was a group of "48 healthy volunteers without previous craniofacial pain".

annotation.pico_inter_rat: The intervention described is CO2 intranasal and it is accurately described according to the original input.

annotation.pico_comp_rat: The comparator described is a placebo and it is accurately described according to the original input.

annotation.pico_out_rat: The outcome described is the rating of pain, which is correct compared to the outcome mentioned in the abstract.

target:
This study talks about a type of pain that happens in the face and head. Scientists have found in some animal experiments that letting them breathe in CO2 - the gas we breathe out - can help with this pain. They thought it might work by interacting with certain nerves in our nose. So, they wanted to see if the same thing could help humans too. 

They first tested it on healthy volunteers who didn't have any head or face pain before. They used capsaicin - the stuff that makes chili peppers hot - to cause the pain, then had them breathe in either CO2 or regular air. They did this in two different ways: switching between CO2 and air every minute, or continuously breathing in CO2. The volunteers rated their pain levels every minute.

Unlike the animal experiments, the CO2 didn't help the human volunteers much. It only lowered their pain ratings a little bit - only 5.3%. Even that small effect was lost when the volunteers were asked to breathe in CO2 continuously. 

So, the conclusion is that while it's interesting to see that CO2 has a small effect on this type of pain in humans, it's not enough to be really helpful for treating pain.

annotation.pico_pop_rat: The Population is described as a group of healthy volunteers that didn't have head or face pain before.

annotation.pico_inter_rat: The Intervention is described as inhaling CO2, this is accurate and matching the description from the abstract.

annotation.pico_comp_rat: The placebo mentioned in the abstract is not mentioned in the summary

annotation.pico_out_rat: The summary describes the outcome by the experienced pain level from the volunteers. This matches the description in the abstract.

target: The researchers looked at how a gas called carbon dioxide (CO2) affects pain in people. They used a special machine to give people a tiny bit of capsaicin, which is a substance that can cause pain, in their noses. Then, they gave some of the people CO2 to breathe in through their noses and some of them breathed in air instead. They asked the people to rate their pain on a special scale every 60 seconds for a few minutes. They found out that the CO2 didn't really help much with the pain, and the changes they saw were not big enough to be important. They think that CO2 might help a little bit with pain in some people, but more research is needed to know for sure.

annotation.final_commands: Please explain the methods of the study more - who was included as population?

annotation.pico_pop_rat: The summary only says that there were "people" that received the Capsaicin and afterwards some of them received CO2. The important details about those "peopke" are all missing. The abstract says that the people had to be healthy volunteers that did not have craniofacial pain formerly.

annotation.pico_inter_rat: The intervention is described as CO2 breathed in through the nose which is correct in comparison to the given information from the abstract.

annotation.pico_comp_rat: The comparator is described as "air" which is correct in comparison to the given information from the abstract, yet it is not clearly saying that the air is classified as Placebo.

annotation.pico_out_rat: The outcome is described as rating their pain which is correct in comparison to the given information from the abstract.

annotation.results_rat: The result that CO2 did not help much is described correctly, yet information is missing. The summary does not say that there were two experiments which seems to be important for understanding the sum of the results.

annotation.hal_rationale: An accurate description for the mentioned placebo comparator.
Wrongly added information. It does not help significantly to people, only animals.

ABSTRACT.OBJECTIVE.
There are controversial findings in the literature on the effects of chest physiotherapy on postextubation lung collapse in pediatric age group.  Therefore, we aimed to investigate the efficacy of chest physiotherapy in prevention of postextubation atelectasis in pediatric patients.

ABSTRACT.MATERIALS & METHODS.
In a case-control study from March 2007 to March 2011, two groups of patients (35 patients in each group) susceptible to lung collapse were enrolled in the study. The studied patients had neuromuscular diseases such as spinal muscular atrophy, Guillain-Barre syndrome, critical illness polyneuropathy/myopathy, and cerebral palsy. The patients were randomly divided into two groups (case and control); The case group underwent daily chest physiotherapy through vibrator and chest percussion and the control group was under supervision. In the latter group, the underlying disease was treated and the lung collapse was managed, if occurred.

ABSTRACT.RESULTS.
The frequency of atelectasis was lower in the case group who received prophylactic chest physiotherapy compared to the control group (16.6% vs. 40%).

ABSTRACT.CONCLUSION.
Chest physiotherapy as well as appropriate and regular change of position can considerably reduce the rate of pulmonary collapse in pediatric patients.
target:
This study investigated the efficacy of chest physiotherapy in preventing post-extubation atelectasis in pediatric patients.

The study included 35 patients with neuromuscular diseases who were susceptible to lung collapse. The patients were randomly divided into two groups, a case group that received daily chest physiotherapy through a vibrator and chest percussion, and a control group that was monitored and treated for any lung collapse that occurred.

The results showed that the frequency of atelectasis was lower in the case group (16.6%) compared to the control group (40%).

The study concluded that chest physiotherapy, in addition to appropriate and regular change of position, can considerably reduce the rate of pulmonary collapse in pediatric patients.</s><s>

annotation.pico_pop_rat: The population is described as 35 patients with neuromuscular diseases which is not fully correct in comparison to the given information from the abstract because there it says that there are two groups of patience with the mentioned above sickness, but 35 patience in each group - so a total of 70.

annotation.pico_inter_rat: The interventions described in the summary macth the ones mentioned in the abstract: daily chest physiotherapy through a vibrator and chest percussion.

annotation.pico_comp_rat: The summary describes the comparator as a control group that was monitored and treated for any lung collapse that occurred, which is matching the description from the abstract.

source:
ABSTRACT.OBJECTIVE.
There are controversial findings in the literature on the effects of chest physiotherapy on postextubation lung collapse in pediatric age group.  Therefore, we aimed to investigate the efficacy of chest physiotherapy in prevention of postextubation atelectasis in pediatric patients.

ABSTRACT.MATERIALS & METHODS.
In a case-control study from March 2007 to March 2011, two groups of patients (35 patients in each group) susceptible to lung collapse were enrolled in the study. The studied patients had neuromuscular diseases such as spinal muscular atrophy, Guillain-Barre syndrome, critical illness polyneuropathy/myopathy, and cerebral palsy. The patients were randomly divided into two groups (case and control); The case group underwent daily chest physiotherapy through vibrator and chest percussion and the control group was under supervision. In the latter group, the underlying disease was treated and the lung collapse was managed, if occurred.

ABSTRACT.RESULTS.
The frequency of atelectasis was lower in the case group who received prophylactic chest physiotherapy compared to the control group (16.6% vs. 40%).

ABSTRACT.CONCLUSION.
Chest physiotherapy as well as appropriate and regular change of position can considerably reduce the rate of pulmonary collapse in pediatric patients.
target:
This passage is about a study that was done to see if a special type of therapy for your chest, called chest physiotherapy, could prevent a condition known as lung collapse in kids, after they have a tube removed from their throat. The study included kids who had certain types of muscle or nerve diseases. They had two groups, one group that got chest physiotherapy and another group that was just watched and treated for their disease but they didn't get the chest physiotherapy.

After doing the study, they found out that the kids who had the chest physiotherapy had less lung collapses compared to the group that didn't have the therapy (16.6% vs 40%). The researchers concluded that chest physiotherapy can help reduce the chances of lung collapse in patients, especially when it's combined with changing the child's position regularly.

annotation.final_commands: Please describe the size of the patients groups.

annotation.pico_pop_rat: The summary describes the population accurately as a group of kids that had certain types of muscle or nerve diseases, only the size of the groups is missing when compared to the abstract.

annotation.pico_inter_rat: The intervention is described as receiving chest therapy, yet the summary lacks to mention that the physiotherapy is applied through a vibrator, done daily and followed with chest percussion. The abstract is more detailed.

annotation.pico_comp_rat: The comparator is only described as not receiving physiotherapy, but is missing to mention that the underlying disease was still treated and a lung collapse was managed, if occured.

annotation.pico_out_rat: The outcome is described correctly and compared to the abstract accurately as the frequency of atelectasis.

ABSTRACT.PURPOSE:
To evaluate the analgesic effect, efficacy and safety of aceclofenac controlled release (CR) in patients with chronic knee osteoarthritis (OA).

ABSTRACT.MATERIALS AND METHODS:
A total of 125 subjects with chronic knee OA were randomly divided into two groups: one group (n=62) was administered aceclofenac CR once daily and the other (n=63), aceclofenac immediate release (IR) twice a day for 4 weeks. A 100-mm visual analogue scale (VAS), Knee injury and Osteoarthritis Outcome Score (KOOS) and range of motoin (ROM) were evaluated as the outcome measures. To evaluate the safety of the drug, adverse events, vital signs, physical examination findings, clinical laboratory values and electrocardiographic findings were evaluated.

ABSTRACT.RESULTS:
The VAS, KOOS and ROM were improved after 4 weeks of administration in both groups, but the differences between the two groups were not statistically significant. Significant differences between the two groups were not shown in the evaluation of the adverse events, vital sign, physical examination results, clinical laboratory values, and electrocardiography.

ABSTRACT.CONCLUSIONS:
The aceclofenac CR and aceclofenac IR were equally effective in patients with chronic knee OA and the clinical trial results didn't show any significant difference in safety. The new aceclofenac CR formulation was found to be effective and safe with the practical advantage of once daily administration.

annotation.final_commands: Please explain shortly what knee osteoarthritis is. Please explain what type of medicine aceclofenac is. Please explain shortly what sort of scores the VAS,KOOS and ROM is.

annotation.pico_pop_rat: The population is described as a group of 125 subjects, yet it is missing that these patients had chronic knee osteoarthritis and were not a random group of volunteers.

annotation.pico_inter_rat: The intervention in the summary is described as receiving aceclofenac CR once daily, which is correct and matching the information given in the abstract.

annotation.pico_comp_rat: The comparator in the summary is described as receiving aceclofenac IR twice a day for 4 weeks, which is correct and matching the information given in the abstract

annotation.pico_out_rat: The outcome in the summary is described as a score in the VAS,KOOS and ROM, next to the evaluation by assessing adverse events, vital signs, physical examination findings, clinical laboratory values and electrocardiographic findings, which is correct and matching the information given in the abstract.

ABSTRACT.PURPOSE.
A link between poor sleep quality and Alzheimer's disease (AD) has recently been suggested. Since endogenous melatonin levels are already reduced at preclinical AD stages, it is important to ask whether replenishing the missing hormone would be beneficial in AD and whether any such effects would be related to the presence of sleep disorder in patients.

ABSTRACT.PATIENTS AND METHODS.
The effects of add-on prolonged-release melatonin (PRM) (2 mg) to standard therapy on cognitive functioning and sleep were investigated in 80 patients (men [50.7%], women [49.3%], average age 75.3 years [range, 52–85 years]) diagnosed with mild to moderate AD, with and without insomnia comorbidity, and receiving standard therapy (acetylcholinesterase inhibitors with or without memantine). In this randomized, double-blind, parallel-group study, patients were treated for 2 weeks with placebo and then randomized (1:1) to receive 2 mg of PRM or placebo nightly for 24 weeks, followed by 2 weeks placebo. The AD Assessment Scale–Cognition (ADAS-Cog), Instrumental Activities of Daily Living (IADL), Mini–Mental State Examination (MMSE), sleep, as assessed by the Pittsburgh Sleep Quality Index (PSQI) and a daily sleep diary, and safety parameters were measured.

ABSTRACT.RESULTS.
Patients treated with PRM (24 weeks) had significantly better cognitive performance than those treated with placebo, as measured by the IADL (P=0.004) and MMSE (P=0.044). Mean ADAS-Cog did not differ between the groups. Sleep efficiency, as measured by the PSQI, component 4, was also better with PRM (P=0.017). In the comorbid insomnia (PSQI ≥6) subgroup, PRM treatment resulted in significant and clinically meaningful effects versus the placebo, in mean IADL (P=0.032), MMSE score (+1.5 versus −3 points) (P=0.0177), and sleep efficiency (P=0.04). Median ADAS-Cog values (−3.5 versus +3 points) (P=0.045) were significantly better with PRM. Differences were more significant at longer treatment duration. PRM was well tolerated, with an adverse event profile similar to that of placebo.

ABSTRACT.CONCLUSION.
Add-on PRM has positive effects on cognitive functioning and sleep maintenance in AD patients compared with placebo, particularly in those with insomnia comorbidity. The results suggest a possible causal link between poor sleep and cognitive decline.
target: This study investigated the effects of prolonged-release melatonin (PRM) on cognitive functioning and sleep in patients with Alzheimer's disease (AD). The results showed that PRM improved cognitive performance, sleep efficiency and insomnia symptoms in AD patients. These findings suggest a possible causal link between poor sleep and cognitive decline.</s><s>

annotation.final_commands: Please give more information about the patients and method of the study.Please explain what melatonin is and what it does.

annotation.pico_pop_rat: The summary does not give any information about the set up and study-group itself. It should include the information that 80 patients with early stage AD, ages 52-85 were included in the study.

annotation.pico_inter_rat: The summary does not give any information about the set up and study-group itself. It should include the information that one group was given 2mg of PRM for 24 weeks every night.

annotation.pico_comp_rat: he summary does not give any information about the set up and study-group itself. It should include the information that the comparatr group did only receive a placebo for a total of 26 weeks.

It does say in the summary that sleep efficiency improved.

target: Scientists were curious about a hormone called melatonin that we don't have as much of when we don't sleep well and when we get older. They gave extra melatonin to some older people who have Alzheimer's disease, which can make you forget things. Some of those people also had trouble sleeping. The scientists did a test and found out that the people who took the extra melatonin remembered things better and slept better than the people who didn't take it, especially those who had trouble sleeping. This might mean that not sleeping well could also cause memory problems. The extra melatonin didn't make people feel sick and was safe to take. So, it looks like it could be helpful for people with Alzheimer's disease, especially if they also have problems with sleeping.

annotation.final_commands: Please explain the method of the study more.

annotation.pico_pop_rat: The population described in the summary  as "some older people who have Alzheimer's disease", which is correct in the broader sense, yet sounds too vague as the Abstract specifies the population of the study specifically as 80 patience with early onset AD, ages 52-85.

annotation.pico_inter_rat: The intervention  is described in the summary as melantonin, which is correct, yet it is missing the fact noted in the abstract that the melantonin given is "prolonges-release Melantonin".

annotation.pico_comp_rat: The summary only mentions that some people did not receive extra melantonin, it does not say that the non-melantonin group received as a comparator a placebo.

annotation.pico_out_rat: The outcomes mentioned in the summary are the quality of sleep and ability to remember things. Also it mentions as outcomes how well people felt taking melantonin. These outcomes are the same as mentioned in the abstract.

annotation.hal_rationale: It is right that low levels of melatonin can go hand in hand with sleeping unwell but not as a sure corelation as described here. Also it is not right that we have lower levels of it as we grow older. The Abstract says that it was discovered that patience suffering from early stages of AD happen to habe lower levels of melantonin.
It is correct that AD goes hand in hand with a worsened cognitive function  but that is not the exclusive effect of AD.

ABSTRACT.BACKGROUND:.
The aim of this study is to compare and evaluate the clinical outcome of the envelope-type of coronally advanced flap (CAF) alone versus envelope type of coronally advanced flap plus type I collagen membrane (NEOMEM) in the treatment of multiple buccal gingival recessions, using the split mouth study.

ABSTRACT.MATERIALS AND METHODS:.
Ten patients in the age group of 20-50 years showing bilateral gingival recessions were treated. The defects in each patient were randomly assigned as Group A, which were treated with the envelope type of CAF, and those in Group B were treated with envelope type of CAF along with the Type I collagen membrane (NEOMEM). The recession depth (RD), probing depth (PD), clinical attachment level (CAL), and width of the keratinized tissue (KT) were measured at baseline, at three and six month intervals.

ABSTRACT.RESULTS:.
Forty-six Miller's class I and II gingival recessions were treated. In the CAF + Type I collagen membrane (NEOMEM)-treated (Group B) sites the baseline gingival recession was 2.34 ± 0.48 mm, while in the CAFtreated (Group A) sites it was 2.52 ± 0.84 mm. Both the treatments resulted in significant recession depth reduction (P < 0.001), but the reduction was significantly greater (P < 0.01) for Group B than Group A. The probing depth changes were significant (P < 0.01) for both groups, but the difference was nonsignificant. Similarly, a significant gain of CAL was seen in Group B (2.23 ± 0.75 mm, P < 0.001) as well as in group A (1.60 ± 0.86 mm, P < 0.001) showing a significant difference (P < 0.01) between the two groups. The width of keratinized tissue was also significantly (P < 0.001) increased in both groups, but the increase was significantly greater (P < 0.001) in group B (2.30 ± 1.06 mm) than in group A (1.21 ± 0.67 mm).

ABSTRACT.CONCLUSION:.
The envelope type of CAF along with Type I collagen membrane (NEOMEM) was more effective than envelope type of CAF alone, in producing root coverage in multiple gingival recession defects, associated with gain in CAL as also in the width of KT.
target: This study compared the effectiveness of an envelope-type coronally advanced flap (CAF) alone with the addition of a type I collagen membrane (NEOMEM) in the treatment of multiple buccal gingival recessions. The results showed that the combination of the CAF and the type I collagen membrane was more effective than the CAF alone, producing greater root coverage, gain in clinical attachment level (CAL), and wider keratinized tissue.</s><s>

annotation.final_commands: Please explain medical terms like: envelope-type coronally advanced flap, collagen membrane, clinical attachment level, keratinized tissue.

annotation.pico_pop_rat: The population of 46 Miller's class I and II gingival recessions is not mentioned in the summary.

annotation.pico_inter_rat: The intervention mentioned is a treatment with CAF and NEOMEM together, which is correct compared to the information given in the abstract.

annotation.pico_comp_rat: The comparator is mentioned as "an envelope-type coronally advanced flap (CAF) alone", yet the wording of the whole sentence does not make it very clear, that one group was only treated with CAF alone as a comparator group to the group that received both. Yet later in the summary it says again that there were people only treated with the CAF, so I chose to say that "The comparator is mentioned, and described accurately".

annotation.pico_out_rat: The outcomes mentioned in the summary are root coverage, clinical attachment level (CAL), and width of keratinized tissue - it is missing the outcome recession depth that is mentioned in the abstract.

annotation.results_rat: The summary says that the combined treatment was more effective than the CAF alone, which is not correct compared to this result.
The summary does say that the combined treatment showed better results in KT than the CAF alone, but it is missing the information that there was an increase also when treated with CAF alone.

annotation.pico_pop_rat: The summary only referes to the population of the study as "patience", not giving any of the additional information that are given in the abstract.

annotation.pico_inter_rat: The intervention is described as a special surgical treatment added by a collagen membrane, which is correct (eventhough put in less specific terms) compared to the abstract.

ABSTRACT.BACKGROUND:.
The aim of this study is to compare and evaluate the clinical outcome of the envelope-type of coronally advanced flap (CAF) alone versus envelope type of coronally advanced flap plus type I collagen membrane (NEOMEM) in the treatment of multiple buccal gingival recessions, using the split mouth study.

ABSTRACT.MATERIALS AND METHODS:.
Ten patients in the age group of 20-50 years showing bilateral gingival recessions were treated. The defects in each patient were randomly assigned as Group A, which were treated with the envelope type of CAF, and those in Group B were treated with envelope type of CAF along with the Type I collagen membrane (NEOMEM). The recession depth (RD), probing depth (PD), clinical attachment level (CAL), and width of the keratinized tissue (KT) were measured at baseline, at three and six month intervals.

ABSTRACT.RESULTS:.
Forty-six Miller's class I and II gingival recessions were treated. In the CAF + Type I collagen membrane (NEOMEM)-treated (Group B) sites the baseline gingival recession was 2.34 ± 0.48 mm, while in the CAFtreated (Group A) sites it was 2.52 ± 0.84 mm. Both the treatments resulted in significant recession depth reduction (P < 0.001), but the reduction was significantly greater (P < 0.01) for Group B than Group A. The probing depth changes were significant (P < 0.01) for both groups, but the difference was nonsignificant. Similarly, a significant gain of CAL was seen in Group B (2.23 ± 0.75 mm, P < 0.001) as well as in group A (1.60 ± 0.86 mm, P < 0.001) showing a significant difference (P < 0.01) between the two groups. The width of keratinized tissue was also significantly (P < 0.001) increased in both groups, but the increase was significantly greater (P < 0.001) in group B (2.30 ± 1.06 mm) than in group A (1.21 ± 0.67 mm).

ABSTRACT.CONCLUSION:.
The envelope type of CAF along with Type I collagen membrane (NEOMEM) was more effective than envelope type of CAF alone, in producing root coverage in multiple gingival recession defects, associated with gain in CAL as also in the width of KT.
target: The study compared how well two different treatments work for people with multiple gum recessions. One treatment used a special type of gum tissue to cover the exposed roots, and the other used a special membrane to help the gum tissue grow back. The study found that using both treatments together worked better than using just one of them. The gum tissue grew back more and the gum recession got smaller.

annotation.final_commands: Please give more information about the methods.

annotation.pico_pop_rat: The populationof the trial is not mentioned in the summary.

annotation.pico_inter_rat: The intervention is described as "a special type of gum tissue to cover the exposed roots" which refers to CAF in easier words, so I would categorize it as a correct statement compared to the abstract.

annotation.pico_comp_rat: The comparator mentioned is "a special membrane to help the gum tissue grow back", which is a correct explaination of NEOMEM according to the abstract.

annotation.pico_out_rat: As outcome only the growth of gum tissue and the size of the gum recession are mentioned. The summary misses to mention the "clinical attachment level (CAL), and width of the keratinized tissue (KT)".

annotation.results_rat: The summary does not clearly mention that both methods caused a significant improvement.
The summary does say that the treatments together caused a greater grow back of gum tissue and a downsize in gum recession but it does not mention the width of kreatinized tissue.

annotation.hal_rationale: Both of these descriptions are accurate explainations for CAF and NEOMEM.

ABSTRACT.OBJECTIVES.
To evaluate the effect of certolizumab pegol (CZP) on productivity outside and within the home, and on participation in family, social and leisure activities in adult patients with psoriatic arthritis (PsA).

ABSTRACT.METHODS.
RAPID-PsA (NCT01087788) is a phase 3, double-blind, placebo-controlled trial. 409 patients with active PsA were randomised 1:1:1 to placebo, CZP 200 mg every 2 weeks (Q2W) or CZP 400 mg every 4 weeks (Q4W). The arthritis-specific Work Productivity Survey (WPS) assessed the impact of PsA on paid work and household productivity, and participation in social activities during the preceding month. WPS responses were compared between treatment arms using a non-parametric bootstrap-t method.

ABSTRACT.RESULTS.
At baseline, 56.6%, 60.1% and 61.5% of placebo, CZP 200 mg Q2W and CZP 400 mg Q4W patients were employed. By week 24, employed CZP patients reported an average of 1.0–1.8 and 3.0–3.9 fewer days of absenteeism and presenteeism, respectively, per month compared with 1.0 and 0.3 fewer days for placebo patients (p<0.05). Within the home, by week 24, CZP patients reported an average of 3.0–3.5 household work days gained per month versus 1.0 day for placebo (p<0.05). CZP patients also reported fewer days with reduced household productivity or days lost for participation in family, social and leisure activities. Improvements with CZP were seen as early as week 4 and continued to week 24.

ABSTRACT.CONCLUSIONS.
CZP treatment significantly improved productivity at paid work and within the home, and resulted in greater participation in social activities for PsA patients.

ABSTRACT.TRIAL REGISTRATION NUMBER.
NCT01087788.

target:
This passage is about a scientific experiment that tested a medicine called CZP on people who have a disease called psoriatic arthritis. This disease can cause a lot of pain and problems that can make it hard for people to do their job or chores at home. 

In the experiment, they divided people into three groups. The first group got a fake pill with no medicine, the second group got a small amount of CZP every 2 weeks, and the third group got a larger amount of CZP every 4 weeks. They asked these people questions about how many days they missed work or couldn't do their household chores, and how much they were able to join in family, social and leisure activities.

They found out that people who got CZP missed fewer days of work, were able to do more chores at home, and could join family activities more than those who took the fake pill. The people with CZP started to feel better and do more activities as early as the 4th week and continued to improve until the 24th week of the treatment. 

So, the experiment showed that CZP medicine can help people with psoriatic arthritis do their jobs, chores, and activities better than before.

ABSTRACT.
Reinforcement signals in the striatum are known to be crucial for mediating the subjective rewarding effects of acute drug intake. It is proposed that these effects may be more involved in early phases of drug addiction, whereas negative reinforcement effects may occur more in later stages of the illness. This study used resting-state functional magnetic resonance imaging to explore whether acute heroin substitution also induced positive reinforcement effects in striatal brain regions of protracted heroin-maintained patients. Using independent component analysis and a dual regression approach, we compared resting-state functional connectivity (rsFC) strengths within the basal ganglia/limbic network across a group of heroin-dependent patients receiving both an acute infusion of heroin and placebo and 20 healthy subjects who received placebo only. Subsequent correlation analyses were performed to test whether the rsFC strength under heroin exposure correlated with the subjective rewarding effect and with plasma concentrations of heroin and its main metabolites morphine. Relative to the placebo treatment in patients, heroin significantly increased rsFC of the left putamen within the basal ganglia/limbic network, the extent of which correlated positively with patients' feelings of rush and with the plasma level of morphine. Furthermore, healthy controls revealed increased rsFC of the posterior cingulate cortex/precuneus in this network relative to the placebo treatment in patients. Our results indicate that acute heroin substitution induces a subjective rewarding effect via increased striatal connectivity in heroin-dependent patients, suggesting that positive reinforcement effects in the striatum still occur after protracted maintenance therapy.
target: This study used functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI) to explore whether acute heroin substitution also induces positive reinforcement effects in the striatum of heroin-dependent patients. The results showed that heroin increased the connectivity of the left putamen, a part of the basal ganglia/limbic network, in heroin-dependent patients. This increased connectivity was correlated with the patients' feelings of rush and with the plasma level of morphine. In addition, healthy controls revealed increased connectivity of the posterior cingulate cortex/precuneus in this network relative to the placebo treatment in patients. These findings suggest that positive reinforcement effects in the striatum still occur after protracted maintenance therapy.</s><s>

target: This study was trying to see how heroin affects the brain of people who have been using the drug for a long period of time. They saw that when people used heroin after not using it for a while, certain areas in their brain linked more strongly. These stronger links made the people feel a rush of enjoyment and this feeling was stronger if there was more heroin in their body. This suggests that even after using heroin for a long time, the drug can still create feelings of enjoyment in the brain.

target: This means that when people take heroin, their brain gets a little happy feeling. It's like when you eat your favorite food and it tastes really good. The heroin makes the brain happy by connecting with other parts of the brain that help us feel good. And the more connected these parts are, the happier the brain gets. But sometimes, the brain can get too happy and that can be bad. So, scientists studied what happens in the brain when people take heroin and they found out that even after a long time of taking heroin, the brain still gets happy when it takes the drug. It's like the brain is still trying to get that happy feeling even after a while.

ABSTRACT.PURPOSE.
To prospectively compare SIRT and DEB-TACE for treating hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC).

ABSTRACT.METHODS.
From 04/2010–07/2012, 24 patients with histologically proven unresectable N0, M0 HCCs were randomized 1:1 to receive SIRT or DEB-TACE. SIRT could be repeated once in case of recurrence; while, TACE was repeated every 6 weeks until no viable tumor tissue was detected by MRI or contraindications prohibited further treatment. Patients were followed-up by MRI every 3 months; the final evaluation was 05/2013.

ABSTRACT.RESULTS.
Both groups were comparable in demographics (SIRT: 8males/4females, mean age 72 ± 7 years; TACE: 10males/2females, mean age 71 ± 9 years), initial tumor load (1 patient ≥25 % in each group), and BCLC (Barcelona Clinic Liver Cancer) stage (SIRT: 12×B; TACE 1×A, 11×B). Median progression-free survival (PFS) was 180 days for SIRT versus 216 days for TACE patients (p = 0.6193) with a median TTP of 371 days versus 336 days, respectively (p = 0.5764). Median OS was 592 days for SIRT versus 788 days for TACE patients (p = 0.9271). Seven patients died in each group. Causes of death were liver failure (n = 4 SIRT group), tumor progression (n = 4 TACE group), cardiovascular events, and inconclusive (n = 1 in each group).

ABSTRACT.CONCLUSIONS.
No significant differences were found in median PFS, OS, and TTP. The lower rate of tumor progression in the SIRT group was nullified by a greater incidence of liver failure. This pilot study is the first prospective randomized trial comparing SIRT and TACE for treating HCC, and results can be used for sample size calculations of future studies.
target: This study compared two treatments for hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC): SIRT and transarterial chemoembolization (TACE). Both treatments were given to patients with histologically proven unresectable N0, M0 HCCs. The results showed that both treatments had similar median progression-free survival (PFS) and overall survival (OS). However, the SIRT group had a lower rate of tumor progression compared to the TACE group. Additionally, the TACE group had a greater incidence of liver failure. These results can be used to inform future sample size calculations for similar studies.</s><s>

This information can help them decide how many people they need for their future studies comparing these treatments.

target: The study compared two ways of treating liver cancer. One way is called SIRT, and the other way is called TACE. The study found out that the two ways are almost the same in terms of how long the cancer stays away, how long the patient lives, and how often the cancer comes back. The study also found that the patients who got SIRT had more liver problems, but the patients who got TACE had more cancer problems.
